moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 d5 3. e3 g6 4. c4: I call this position Generic 1.  It is pretty easy to play as White against almost anything Black plays.
moves.4... Bg7 5. Nc3 O-O 6. cxd5 Nxd5 7. Qb3: Now that both White and Black are fully developed, I think Black is a little better here.  The Nd5 is strong and their are possibilities to dislodge White's d4 pawn.
moves.15... Qe7 16. Rab1 Rfd8 17. Qe1 Nf6: I was surprised by this move, considering the strength of the Nd5.  Here it eventually leads just to an exchange.
moves.18. Nd2 Ne4 19. Nxe4 Bxe4 20. Bd3 Bb7: I think Black is still a little better here because the Bishops have better diagonals.
moves.21. Bf1 c5: This is the critical moment.  Black tries to break up White's center and take the initiative.
moves.22. dxc5 Rxd1 23. Qxd1 Bxb2: I was expecting Rd8 here, to force my Q off the open file.
moves.24. Rxb2 bxc5 25. bxc5 Rxc5: This allows White a tactic to remove the defender and win a piece.
moves.28. Qd4+: White will win the R back and be up a full piece.  Black resigned here.  I think Black had the better of things positionally, but just missed a tactic.
